node.text: El Dr. Javier Merayo (@javier_merayo), miembro del Comité editorial de Medscape en español, y el Dr. Fabricio Espinosa Ortega comentan aspectos relevantes sobre la frecuencia, el diagnóstico, valor de los anticuerpos y manejo de las miopatías inflamatorias o miositis. ¿Conocen cuáles son las más frecuentes en su región?

node.text:
A conversation with Abraham Verghese MD, Eric Topol MD, and Danielle Ofri MD about the role of writing during the Covid pandemic. Join the premiere on Tuesday March 23 at 7 pm EST 
@blreview YouTube Page
tinyURL / BLRViral

Readings from today:
"A Doctor's Pandemic Diary" by Danielle Ofri MD (from the New Yorker)
Evocation (Streets) by Jeanette Clough (from BLR)

@blreview @danielle_ofri

node.text: Join me, @drhansamd and DrMeganRanney to chat about burnout. Watch our mini doc on @medscape- The Doctors Dilemma of overcoming burnout has solutions. And tell your stories , please. @medscapepsych #iambroken

node.title: Is burnout worse with all that’s going on with COVID? #iambroken

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Medscape on August 14, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Medscape Clinical Trend: Statins⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In encouraging news, statins were again linked to lower COVID-19 mortality. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The findings come from an analysis of data from the AHA's COVID-19 CVD Registry on more than 10,000 patients at 104 hospitals across the US and were published in PLOS One. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Most patients in the study (71%) had either cardiovascular disease, hypertension, or both. Prior to admission, 42% used statins, with 7% taking statins alone and 35% taking statins plus antihypertensives.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Investigators have reiterated that these findings do not suggest that individuals who are not currently taking statins should begin doing so to lower their risk for COVID mortality; however, experts do suggest that those with indications for the drugs should see this as another reason to start taking them if they are not already doing so. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The theory is not necessarily that statins have direct anti-COVID effects but that they are probably helping to stabilize coronary disease. This means that patients are less likely to die from stroke or myocardial infarction, allowing more time and strength for COVID-19 recovery.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
There was much more statin news this week. Tap the link in bio to review all the data. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#cardiology #cardiologie #cardiologist #cardiologista #heart #physician #doctor #medstudent #medicalstudent #futuredoctor #medicine #cardiovasculardisease #Medscape #statins #hypertension #cardiología #physicianassistant

node.text:
Statins May Improve Outcomes in Some Breast Cancer⁠
⁠
Statin use is tied to longer survival in women with triple-negative breast cancer (#TNBC), according to the first study that was adequately powered to investigate this association.⁠
⁠
TNBC, which lacks estrogen and progesterone receptors and excess HER2 protein, makes up roughly 10% to 20% of breast-cancer diagnoses. ⁠
⁠
It's a highly aggressive subtype and has a poor prognosis with limited treatment options.⁠
⁠
Statins have been shown to target pathways related to breast-cancer carcinogenesis, particularly in TNBC, notes the research published in the journal, Cancer. ⁠
⁠
Statins are known to decrease #breastcancer cell division and increase cell death. ⁠
⁠
This study shows that there is an association between #statins and improved outcomes in TNBC, and the study authors noted that it is time to pursue this idea further in a prospective trial.⁠
⁠
Link in bio for full report.

node.text:
PTSD Tied to a Doubling of Dementia Risk⁠
⁠
#PTSD is associated with up to a 2-fold increased risk of dementia, new research shows.⁠
⁠
Investigators found that individuals with PTSD had a 61% higher risk of dementia, and pooled data from two particular studies showed that PTSD was associated with a doubling of #dementia risk. ⁠
⁠
These results "provide important new evidence of how traumatic experience can impact brain health and how the long-term effects of trauma may impact the brain in many ways, increasing vulnerability to cognitive decline and dementia," senior investigator Vasiliki Orgeta, PhD, associate professor, University College of London, UK, told Medscape Medical News.⁠
⁠
"Our study allows us to conclude for the first time that PTSD is a strong and potentially modifiable risk factor for dementia," she said.⁠
⁠
The study was published online in the British Journal of Psychiatry and analysed on Medscape.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in bio for the full story.⁠

Towards Green PPE⁠
⁠
From surgical masks and gloves to disposable hospital gowns and aprons, the COVID-19 pandemic is creating a mountain of plastic medical waste that is polluting the land and sea – alarming doctors and environmentalists alike.⁠
⁠
One young entrepreneur in Mexico has now invented a range of reusable PPE (personal protective equipment) she hopes will stop tonnes of single-use medical wear ending up in landfill, incinerators and waterways – and save hospitals a fortune.⁠
⁠
Tamara Chayo said disposable PPE not only caused environmental damage, but could spread the virus which survives up to three days on plastics – a particular concern in countries where medical waste management is poor.⁠
⁠
Chayo, a 21-year-old chemical engineering student, co-founded MEDU Protection in mid-2020 to develop a sustainable suit to protect health professionals treating COVID-19 patients at a time when PPE was in short supply.⁠
⁠
The garments are made from a fabric similar to the coating used on surfaces in viral research laboratories.⁠
⁠
Chayo says a doctor can use four disposable gowns a day whereas her PPE can be worn all day and washed 50 times without losing its protective properties - meaning each garment saves 200 plastic items from landfills and incinerators.⁠
⁠
Have you felt concern over the environmental impact of PPE? ANy ideas of your own on how to reduce medical waste. Love to hear about them in the comments.⁠
⁠
And please tap the link in bio to join Medscape.

node.text:
Medscape Clinical Trend: ADUCANUMAB⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Since its approval by the FDA in early June – against its own advisory panel's recommendations – aducanumab has stayed in the headlines. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
An expert panel has now released the first recommendations for its use.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
 In addition to specifying who should and should not be considered for potential use, the panel made recommendations regarding titration, suggesting that aducanumab should be titrated to the highest dose to maximize opportunity for efficiency. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The importance of safety monitoring was also reiterated. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Even if all guidelines are followed, it is unclear whether aducanumab will be effective. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Institute for Clinical and Economic Review asked one of its expert panels, the California Technology Assessment Forum, to consider the available data about aducanumab and requested that members vote on whether evidence suggested a net benefit of aducanumab plus supportive care vs supportive care alone. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
All 15 panelists voted no.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Experts are already warning primary care physicians  about concerns related to the drug. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In a commentary, Kenneth W. Lin suggests that aducanumab may cause healthcare spending to skyrocket and will probably increase pressure on PCPs to screen older patients for mild cognitive impairment during wellness visits or other checkups. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Thoughts on this drug approval? Please leave them in the comments. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Be sure to tap the link in bio to read the full review on this controversial medication.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#alzheimers #dementia #Alzheimersdrug #FDA #FDAapproval #aducanumab #neurology #neurologist #physicianassistant #APRN #medicalstudent #medstudent #medicalresearch

node.text:
ECG Challenge: Dilated Cardiomyopathy⁠
⁠
A 69-year-old man with a history of a dilated cardiomyopathy presents with several hours of palpitations and sudden onset of shortness of breath which prompted a visit to the emergency room. ⁠
⁠
On physical examination his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and his heart rate is 100 bpm. ⁠
⁠
Review the ECG tracing and make your diagnosis.⁠
⁠
Correct response tomorrow. In the meantime you can tap the link in bio to join the Medscape community for free. ⁠
⁠
What is your diagnosis?⁠
⁠
A. Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome⁠
⁠
B. Ventricular tachycardia⁠
⁠
C. Sinus tachycardia with right bundle branch block⁠
⁠
D. Junctional tachycardia with right bundle branch block

node.text:
Promising New Treatment in Liver Cancer⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In patients with advanced liver cancer who were unresponsive to lenvatinib, adding gefitinib led to a clinically meaningful response in a proof-of-concept study.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"We demonstrated that a combination of BRAF and EGFR inhibitors leads to effective tumor control for this group of cancers," sais Dr. Rene Bernards of The Netherlands Cancer Institute in Amsterdam who, along with colleagues, performed the study.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In the current study, he said, "we focused on why liver cancer patients only experience modest clinical benefit from treatment with lenvatinib. We again performed a synthetic lethality CRISPR screen and again found that EGFR activation is the problem."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
However, he added, the study also shows that "patients who have progressed on lenvatinib therapy still benefit from a combination of lenvatinib and gefitinib (an EGFR inhibitor)."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"The take-home message is that rational drug combinations identified through genetic screens are far more likely to deliver clinical benefit than the 'trial and error' approaches that we often see in the clinic today," he noted.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Full report can be found on Medscape. Swipe through this #photogallery to see different views of #HCC.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#livercancer #instaliver #hccsm #crispr #clinicaltrial #medicalrecearch #cancertreatment #cancercare #cancerresearch #oncology #patientpower #fightcancer #immunotherapy

node.text:
Common Chemicals Could Raise Breast Cancer Risk⁠
⁠
Nearly 300 chemicals found in everything from pesticides to food additives, cosmetics and even water could be increasing the risk of breast cancer in American women, a new study shows.⁠
⁠
After combing through US Environmental Protection Agency testing data on more than 2,000 chemicals, scientists identified 296 that stimulated laboratory cells to produce estrogen or progesterone — hormones known to fuel breast tumors, they report in Environmental Health Perspectives.⁠
⁠
"The connection between estrogen and progesterone and breast cancer is well established. So we should be extremely cautious about chemicals in products that increase levels of these hormones in the body," said co-author Ruthann A. Rudel, research director at Silent Spring Institute in Newton, Massachusetts.⁠
⁠
The chemicals — which could be virtually anywhere in homes, furniture, food, water, shampoos, hair dyes and pesticides — were more likely to be carcinogenic or developmental or reproductive toxicants than not, Rudel said. ⁠
⁠
Rudel and her co-author, Silent Spring scientist Bethsaida Cardona, urged regulators and manufacturers to view their research as a wake-up call to test chemicals for safety.⁠
⁠
Additionally, she also called for stricter regulation of chemicals that could promote the growth of breast cancer.⁠
⁠
Link in bio for full report, link to research and references.

node.text:
Medical Monday Case Challenge: #TAVR⁠
⁠
Which of the following is NOT a contraindication to TAVR and exclusion criteria for the valve replacement procedure?⁠
⁠
A) Severe left ventricular dysfunction with a left ventricular ejection fraction of < 20%⁠
⁠
B) Bicuspid aortic stenosis ⁠
⁠
C) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with or without obstruction⁠
⁠
D) Severe pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction⁠
⁠
There’s a new tool that predicts the risk of bleeding after TAVR. Tap the link in bio to evaluate its clinical implications. �⁠
⁠
Answer revealed in comments tomorrow.⁠
⁠
⁠
